Comments: The type parameter `T` is the expected shape of the parsed options.
`Arguments<T>` is those options plus `_` and `$0`, and an indexer falling
For the return type / `argv` property, we create a mapped type over
`Arguments<T>` to simplify the inferred type signature in client code.
Types.Name: Argv

Comments: Set key names as equivalent such that updates to a key will propagate to aliases and vice-versa.
Optionally `.alias()` can take an object that maps keys to aliases.
Each key of this object should be the canonical version of the option, and each value should be a string or an array of strings.
Members.Name: alias

Comments: Get the arguments as a plain old object.
Arguments without a corresponding flag show up in the `argv._` array.
The script name or node command is available at `argv.$0` similarly to how `$0` works in bash or perl.
If `yargs` is executed in an environment that embeds node and there's no script name (e.g. Electron or nw.js),
it will ignore the first parameter since it expects it to be the script name. In order to override
this behavior, use `.parse(process.argv.slice(1))` instead of .argv and the first parameter won't be ignored.
Members.Name: argv

Comments: Tell the parser to interpret `key` as an array.
If `.array('foo')` is set, `--foo foo bar` will be parsed as `['foo', 'bar']` rather than as `'foo'`.
Also, if you use the option multiple times all the values will be flattened in one array so `--foo foo --foo bar` will be parsed as `['foo', 'bar']`
When the option is used with a positional, use `--` to tell `yargs` to stop adding values to the array.
Members.Name: array

Comments: Interpret `key` as a boolean. If a non-flag option follows `key` in `process.argv`, that string won't get set as the value of `key`.
`key` will default to `false`, unless a `default(key, undefined)` is explicitly set.
If `key` is an array, interpret all the elements as booleans.
Members.Name: boolean

Comments: Check that certain conditions are met in the provided arguments.
Members.Name: check

Comment.Name: func
Description: Called with two arguments, the parsed `argv` hash and an array of options and their aliases.
If `func` throws or returns a non-truthy value, show the thrown error, usage information, and exit.

Comment.Name: global
Description: Indicates whether `check()` should be enabled both at the top-level and for each sub-command.

Comments: Limit valid values for key to a predefined set of choices, given as an array or as an individual value.
If this method is called multiple times, all enumerated values will be merged together.
Choices are generally strings or numbers, and value matching is case-sensitive.
Optionally `.choices()` can take an object that maps multiple keys to their choices.
Choices can also be specified as choices in the object given to `option()`.
Members.Name: choices

Comments: Provide a synchronous function to coerce or transform the value(s) given on the command line for `key`.
The coercion function should accept one argument, representing the parsed value from the command line, and should return a new value or throw an error.
The returned value will be used as the value for `key` (or one of its aliases) in `argv`.
If the function throws, the error will be treated as a validation failure, delegating to either a custom `.fail()` handler or printing the error message in the console.
Coercion will be applied to a value after all other modifications, such as `.normalize()`.
Optionally `.coerce()` can take an object that maps several keys to their respective coercion function.
You can also map the same function to several keys at one time. Just pass an array of keys as the first argument to `.coerce()`.
If you are using dot-notion or arrays, .e.g., `user.email` and `user.password`, coercion will be applied to the final object that has been parsed
Members.Name: coerce

Comments: Define the commands exposed by your application.
Members.Name: command

Comment.Name: command
Description: Should be a string representing the command or an array of strings representing the command and its aliases.

Comment.Name: description
Description: Use to provide a description for each command your application accepts (the values stored in `argv._`).
Set `description` to false to create a hidden command. Hidden commands don't show up in the help output and aren't available for completion.

Comment.Name: builder
Description: Object to give hints about the options that your command accepts.
Can also be a function. This function is executed with a yargs instance, and can be used to provide advanced command specific help.
Note that when `void` is returned, the handler `argv` object type will not include command-specific arguments.

Comment.Name: handler
Description: Function, which will be executed with the parsed `argv` object.

Comments: Apply command modules from a directory relative to the module calling this method.
Members.Name: commandDir

Comments: Enable bash/zsh-completion shortcuts for commands and options.
If invoked without parameters, `.completion()` will make completion the command to output the completion script.
Members.Name: completion

Comments: Tells the parser that if the option specified by `key` is passed in, it should be interpreted as a path to a JSON config file.
The file is loaded and parsed, and its properties are set as arguments.
Because the file is loaded using Node's require(), the filename MUST end in `.json` to be interpreted correctly.
If invoked without parameters, `.config()` will make --config the option to pass the JSON config file.
Members.Name: config

Comments: Given the key `x` is set, the key `y` must not be set. `y` can either be a single string or an array of argument names that `x` conflicts with.
Optionally `.conflicts()` can accept an object specifying multiple conflicting keys.
Members.Name: conflicts

Comments: Interpret `key` as a boolean flag, but set its parsed value to the number of flag occurrences rather than `true` or `false`. Default value is thus `0`.
Members.Name: count

Comments: Set `argv[key]` to `value` if no option was specified in `process.argv`.
Optionally `.default()` can take an object that maps keys to default values.
The default value can be a `function` which returns a value. The name of the function will be used in the usage string.
Optionally, `description` can also be provided and will take precedence over displaying the value in the usage instructions.
Members.Name: ``default``

Comment.Name: key
Description: If is a string, show the usage information and exit if key wasn't specified in `process.argv`.
If is an array, demand each element.

Comment.Name: msg
Description: If string is given, it will be printed when the argument is missing, instead of the standard error message.

Comments: You can demand a minimum and a maximum number a user can have within your program, as well as provide corresponding error messages if either of the demands is not met.
Members.Name: demandCommand

Comments: Describe a `key` for the generated usage information.
Optionally `.describe()` can take an object that maps keys to descriptions.
Members.Name: describe

Comments: Should yargs attempt to detect the os' locale? Defaults to `true`.
Members.Name: detectLocale

Comments: Tell yargs to parse environment variables matching the given prefix and apply them to argv as though they were command line arguments.
Use the "__" separator in the environment variable to indicate nested options. (e.g. prefix_nested__foo => nested.foo)
If this method is called with no argument or with an empty string or with true, then all env vars will be applied to argv.
Program arguments are defined in this order of precedence:
Env var parsing is disabled by default, but you can also explicitly disable it by calling `.env(false)`, e.g. if you need to undo previous configuration.
Members.Name: env

Comments: A message to print at the end of the usage instructions
Members.Name: epilog

Comments: A message to print at the end of the usage instructions
Members.Name: epilogue

Comments: Give some example invocations of your program.
Inside `cmd`, the string `$0` will get interpolated to the current script name or node command for the present script similar to how `$0` works in bash or perl.
Examples will be printed out as part of the help message.
Members.Name: example

Comments: Manually indicate that the program should exit, and provide context about why we wanted to exit. Follows the behavior set by `.exitProcess().`
Members.Name: exit

Comments: By default, yargs exits the process when the user passes a help flag, the user uses the `.version` functionality, validation fails, or the command handler fails.
Calling `.exitProcess(false)` disables this behavior, enabling further actions after yargs have been validated.
Members.Name: exitProcess

Comments: Method to execute when a failure occurs, rather than printing the failure message.
Members.Name: fail

Comment.Name: func
Description: Is called with the failure message that would have been printed, the Error instance originally thrown and yargs state when the failure occurred.

Comments: Allows to programmatically get completion choices for any line.
Members.Name: getCompletion

Comment.Name: args
Description: An array of the words in the command line to complete.

Comment.Name: done
Description: The callback to be called with the resulting completions.

Comments: Indicate that an option (or group of options) should not be reset when a command is executed
Members.Name: ``global``

Comments: Given a key, or an array of keys, places options under an alternative heading when displaying usage instructions
Members.Name: group

Comments: Hides a key from the generated usage information. Unless a `--show-hidden` option is also passed with `--help` (see `showHidden()`).
Members.Name: hide

Comments: Configure an (e.g. `--help`) and implicit command that displays the usage string and exits the process.
By default yargs enables help on the `--help` option.
Note that any multi-char aliases (e.g. `help`) used for the help option will also be used for the implicit command.
If there are no multi-char aliases (e.g. `h`), then all single-char aliases will be used for the command.
If invoked without parameters, `.help()` will use `--help` as the option and help as the implicit command to trigger help output.
Members.Name: help

Comments: Given the key `x` is set, it is required that the key `y` is set.
y` can either be the name of an argument to imply, a number indicating the position of an argument or an array of multiple implications to associate with `x`.
Optionally `.implies()` can accept an object specifying multiple implications.
Members.Name: implies

Comments: Return the locale that yargs is currently using.
By default, yargs will auto-detect the operating system's locale so that yargs-generated help content will display in the user's language.
Members.Name: locale

Comments: Override the auto-detected locale from the user's operating system with a static locale.
Note that the OS locale can be modified by setting/exporting the `LC_ALL` environment variable.
Members.Name: locale

Comments: Define global middleware functions to be called first, in list order, for all cli command.
Members.Name: middleware

Comment.Name: callbacks
Description: Can be a function or a list of functions. Each callback gets passed a reference to argv.

Comment.Name: applyBeforeValidation
Description: Set to `true` to apply middleware before validation. This will execute the middleware prior to validation checks, but after parsing.

Comments: The number of arguments that should be consumed after a key. This can be a useful hint to prevent parsing ambiguity.
Optionally `.nargs()` can take an object of `key`/`narg` pairs.
Members.Name: nargs

Comments: The key provided represents a path and should have `path.normalize()` applied.
Members.Name: normalize

Comments: Tell the parser to always interpret key as a number.
If `key` is an array, all elements will be parsed as numbers.
If the option is given on the command line without a value, `argv` will be populated with `undefined`.
If the value given on the command line cannot be parsed as a number, `argv` will be populated with `NaN`.
Note that decimals, hexadecimals, and scientific notation are all accepted.
Members.Name: number

Comments: This method can be used to make yargs aware of options that could exist.
You can also pass an opt object which can hold further customization, like `.alias()`, `.demandOption()` etc. for that option.
Members.Name: option

Comments: This method can be used to make yargs aware of options that could exist.
You can also pass an opt object which can hold further customization, like `.alias()`, `.demandOption()` etc. for that option.
Members.Name: options

Comments: Parse `args` instead of `process.argv`. Returns the `argv` object. `args` may either be a pre-processed argv array, or a raw argument string.
Note: Providing a callback to parse() disables the `exitProcess` setting until after the callback is invoked.
Members.Name: parse

Comments: If the arguments have not been parsed, this property is `false`.
If the arguments have been parsed, this contain detailed parsed arguments.
Members.Name: parsed

Comments: Allows to configure advanced yargs features.
Members.Name: parserConfiguration

Comments: Similar to `config()`, indicates that yargs should interpret the object from the specified key in package.json as a configuration object.
Members.Name: pkgConf

Comment.Name: cwd
Description: If provided, the package.json will be read from this location

Comments: Allows you to configure a command's positional arguments with an API similar to `.option()`.
`.positional()` should be called in a command's builder function, and is not available on the top-level yargs instance. If so, it will throw an error.
Members.Name: positional

Comments: Should yargs provide suggestions regarding similar commands if no matching command is found?
Members.Name: recommendCommands

Comments: Set the name of your script ($0). Default is the base filename executed by node (`process.argv[1]`)
Members.Name: scriptName

Comments: Users of your application can install this script in their `.bashrc`, and yargs will provide completion shortcuts for commands and options.
Members.Name: showCompletionScript

Comments: Configure the `--show-hidden` option that displays the hidden keys (see `hide()`).
Members.Name: showHidden

Comment.Name: option
Description: If `boolean`, it enables/disables this option altogether. i.e. hidden keys will be permanently hidden if first argument is `false`.
If `string` it changes the key name ("--show-hidden").

Comments: Print the usage data using the console function consoleLevel for printing.
Members.Name: showHelp

Comments: By default, yargs outputs a usage string if any error is detected.
Use the `.showHelpOnFail()` method to customize this behavior.
Members.Name: showHelpOnFail

Comment.Name: enable
Description: If `false`, the usage string is not output.

Comment.Name: message
Description: Message that is output after the error message.

Comments: Specifies either a single option key (string), or an array of options. If any of the options is present, yargs validation is skipped.
Members.Name: skipValidation

Comments: Any command-line argument given that is not demanded, or does not have a corresponding description, will be reported as an error.
Unrecognized commands will also be reported as errors.
Members.Name: strict

Comments: Tell the parser logic not to interpret `key` as a number or boolean. This can be useful if you need to preserve leading zeros in an input.
If `key` is an array, interpret all the elements as strings.
`.string('_')` will result in non-hyphenated arguments being interpreted as strings, regardless of whether they resemble numbers.
Members.Name: string

Comments: Override the default strings used by yargs with the key/value pairs provided in obj
If you explicitly specify a locale(), you should do so before calling `updateStrings()`.
Members.Name: updateStrings

Comments: Set a usage message to show which commands to use.
Inside `message`, the string `$0` will get interpolated to the current script name or node command for the present script similar to how `$0` works in bash or perl.
If the optional `description`/`builder`/`handler` are provided, `.usage()` acts an an alias for `.command()`.
This allows you to use `.usage()` to configure the default command that will be run as an entry-point to your application
and allows you to provide configuration for the positional arguments accepted by your program:
Members.Name: usage

Comments: Add an option (e.g. `--version`) that displays the version number (given by the version parameter) and exits the process.
By default yargs enables version for the `--version` option.
If no arguments are passed to version (`.version()`), yargs will parse the package.json of your module and use its version value.
If the boolean argument `false` is provided, it will disable `--version`.
Members.Name: version

Comments: Format usage output to wrap at columns many columns.
By default wrap will be set to `Math.min(80, windowWidth)`. Use `.wrap(null)` to specify no column limit (no right-align).
Use `.wrap(yargs.terminalWidth())` to maximize the width of yargs' usage instructions.
Members.Name: wrap

Comments: Look for command modules in all subdirectories and apply them as a flattened (non-hierarchical) list.
Members.Name: recurse

Comments: The types of files to look for when requiring command modules.
Members.Name: extensions

Comments: A synchronous function called for each command module encountered.
Returns `commandObject` to include the command; any falsy value to exclude/skip it.
Members.Name: visit

Comments: string or array of strings, alias(es) for the canonical option key, see `alias()`
Members.Name: alias

Comments: boolean, interpret option as an array, see `array()`
Members.Name: array

Comments: boolean, interpret option as a boolean flag, see `boolean()`
Members.Name: boolean

Comments: value or array of values, limit valid option arguments to a predefined set, see `choices()`
Members.Name: choices

Comments: function, coerce or transform parsed command line values into another value, see `coerce()`
Members.Name: coerce

Comments: boolean, interpret option as a path to a JSON config file, see `config()`
Members.Name: config

Comments: function, provide a custom config parsing function, see `config()`
Members.Name: configParser

Comments: string or object, require certain keys not to be set, see `conflicts()`
Members.Name: conflicts

Comments: boolean, interpret option as a count of boolean flags, see `count()`
Members.Name: count

Comments: value, set a default value for the option, see `default()`
Members.Name: ``default``

Comments: string, use this description for the default value in help content, see `default()`
Members.Name: defaultDescription

Comments: boolean or string, demand the option be given, with optional error message, see `demandOption()`
Members.Name: demandOption

Comments: string, the option description for help content, see `describe()`
Members.Name: desc

Comments: string, the option description for help content, see `describe()`
Members.Name: describe

Comments: string, the option description for help content, see `describe()`
Members.Name: description

Comments: boolean, indicate that this key should not be reset when a command is invoked, see `global()`
Members.Name: ``global``

Comments: string, when displaying usage instructions place the option under an alternative group heading, see `group()`
Members.Name: group

Comments: don't display option in help output.
Members.Name: hidden

Comments: string or object, require certain keys to be set, see `implies()`
Members.Name: implies

Comments: number, specify how many arguments should be consumed for the option, see `nargs()`
Members.Name: nargs

Comments: boolean, apply path.normalize() to the option, see `normalize()`
Members.Name: normalize

Comments: boolean, interpret option as a number, `number()`
Members.Name: number

Comments: boolean, require the option be specified with a value, see `requiresArg()`
Members.Name: requiresArg

Comments: boolean, skips validation if the option is present, see `skipValidation()`
Members.Name: skipValidation

Comments: boolean, interpret option as a string, see `string()`
Members.Name: string

Comments: string or array of strings, see `alias()`
Members.Name: alias

Comments: value or array of values, limit valid option arguments to a predefined set, see `choices()`
Members.Name: choices

Comments: function, coerce or transform parsed command line values into another value, see `coerce()`
Members.Name: coerce

Comments: string or object, require certain keys not to be set, see `conflicts()`
Members.Name: conflicts

Comments: value, set a default value for the option, see `default()`
Members.Name: ``default``

Comments: string, the option description for help content, see `describe()`
Members.Name: desc

Comments: string, the option description for help content, see `describe()`
Members.Name: describe

Comments: string, the option description for help content, see `describe()`
Members.Name: description

Comments: string or object, require certain keys to be set, see `implies()`
Members.Name: implies

Comments: boolean, apply path.normalize() to the option, see normalize()
Members.Name: normalize

Comments: array of strings (or a single string) representing aliases of `exports.command`, positional args defined in an alias are ignored
Members.Name: aliases

Comments: object declaring the options the command accepts, or a function accepting and returning a yargs instance
Members.Name: builder

Comments: string (or array of strings) that executes this command when given on the command line, first string may contain positional args
Members.Name: command

Comments: string used as the description for the command in help text, use `false` for a hidden command
Members.Name: describe

Comments: a function which will be passed the parsed argv.
Members.Name: handler
